Headline.Para: EDITORIAL; Time to relook total expense ratios of funds in CPF Investment Scheme

LeadPara.Para: THE Government's move to cut and eventually eliminate the sales charges on unit trusts and investment-linked insurance funds (ILPs) in the CPF Investment Scheme is long overdue. From October 1 this year, all funds in the CPFIS are to cap sales charges at 1.5 per cent. From October 2019, investors will pay no sales charges at all.

Wrap fees, which are an annual portfolio advisory fee, will also get the chop. The current cap of 1 per cent per annum on wrap fees will be slashed to 0.7 per cent in October, and further reduced to 0.4 per cent next October.

TailParas.Para: Sales charges on funds in the CPFIS are a legacy of a system started decades ago, when retail funds with high fees were allowed into the scheme.To some degree the scrapping of sales charges may be viewed in the context of developments in mature markets such as the UK and Australia where product commissions have been banned in the financial advisory industry, as they are a conflict of interest and incentivise the wrong behaviour. "Churning'' is one such behaviour, where investors are persuaded to switch funds, not because the funds make sense in their portfolios, but because advisers generate lucrative income that way.

Wrap fees are another matter altogether, however. In mature markets, the best practice is to separate and make transparent the cost of advice in the form of an annual wrap fee, distinct from commissions. In Singapore where a sales charge is common, investors believe that advice is free or its cost is bundled into the commission. But do they really get advice? Are they told when to sell or rebalance their holdings? Wrap fees exist because many investors need on-going advice on their portfolios. This is a welcome trend, as it encourages advisers and clients to take a long term view, and aligns both parties' interests. Some advisers who charge an annual fee will rebate product commissions back to clients to ensure their advice is not compromised by potential conflicts. A wrap fee of 0.7 per cent seems reasonable. But at 0.4 per cent including maintenance costs, an adviser may well find the business unsustainable.

The truth is the sales charge is arguably not the main drag on returns. The proverbial elephant in the equation is funds' total expense ratio (TER), the sum of a fund's operating expenses, such as annual management and valuation fees, expressed as a percentage of total assets. For a lump sum investment, the sales charge is a one-time cost. Its impact on returns is significant if the fund is held for a very short period. But if the fund is held for the long term, its effect on returns dwindles to a small fraction. But the TER is a recurring drag on returns, regardless of holding period. The CPF reduced the cap on funds' TERs in 2014, but that did not go far enough. The cap on higher-risk funds' TERs, for instance, was reduced from 1.95 to 1.75 per cent, still too high if, as experts believe, we are in a low-return environment over the long term.

Today, the reality is that plain-vanilla market exposure is commoditised and very cheap. Index funds' TERs can be as little as 25 basis points or less. Globally the pressure on active funds to reduce fees and show consistent outperformance is immense. The rub is that the vast majority of funds in the CPFIS are actively managed, making the value proposition of a good adviser, who can help in fund selection, even more compelling. In the absence of an adviser, the much awaited Lifetime Retirement Investment Scheme (LRIS), which is expected to comprise low-cost index funds, is a feasible option for CPF members who are unable to monitor and screen funds. It is a long time coming.
